educational_objective: Diagnose idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis on chest CT scan.
question_text: A 62-year-old woman is evaluated for an 8-month history of progressive dyspnea, dry cough, and clubbing. She smokes one pack of cigarettes daily.Chest CT scan is shown.
question_stem: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
critique: This patient's chest CT scan suggests idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) (Option C). Typical radiographic changes in IPF include bilateral, subpleural, and basal predominant reticular changes. More advanced disease is associated with traction bronchiectasis with fibrotic cystic changes to the lungs, commonly called "honeycombing" because of their appearance, as shown (arrow). Honeycombing is a pathologic finding and not specific for a single disease, but it is commonly associated with advanced interstitial lung diseases, such as IPF. The presence of honeycombing is associated with a poor prognosis.In contrast, respiratory bronchiolitis–interstitial lung disease is characterized by upper zone–predominant ground-glass opacities with fine centrilobular nodules. Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia and COPD are not typically associated with honeycombing.
